Tunable.name: clear_locomotion_mask
Tunable.description: If enabled, override the locomotion queue mask. This mask controls which Animation Requests and XEvents get blocked during locomotion. By default, the mask blocks everything. If cleared, it blocks nothing. It also lowers the animation track used by locomotion to 9,999 from the default of 10,000. Use with care, ask your GPE.

Tunable.name: interruptible
Tunable.description: When at the routing SoftCap, multi-route behaviors can be interrupted to allow other objects to route. If this value is set to false and this behavior has multiple routes, it won't be interrupted.

TunableEnum.name: object_routing_priority
TunableEnum.description: ObjectRoutingBehaviors with a higher value priority will be allowed to route more often when at the routing SoftCap. Values are defined in ObjectRoutingPriority module tuning.

TunableVariant.name: pre_route_animation
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, the routing object will play this animation before any route planning/following happens.

TunableVariant.name: route
TunableVariant.description: Define how this object routes when this behavior is active.

TunableTuple.name: DEPRECATED_from_participant_type
TunableTuple.description: Do Not Use! This option has been deprecated and replaced with the from_target_object option. That should be able to do anything this can do plus some extra functionality. If you have any questions please see your friendly GPE.

TunableList.name: constraints
TunableList.description: Constraints relative to the relative participant.

TunableTuple.TunableList:

Values <= 0 indicate placement in ocean is invalid." group="General">
<TunableVariant type="None" name="min_water_depth" class="OptionalTunable" default="disabled" display="Min Water Depth" description="(float) If provided, each vertex of the test polygon along with its centroid will be tested to determine whether the ocean water at the test location is at least this deep. Values <= 0 indicate placement on land is valid." group="General">

Tunable.name: animation_context
Tunable.description: Animation Context - If checked, this animation will get a fresh animation context instead of reusing the animation context of its Interaction. Normally, animation contexts are shared across an entire Super Interaction. This allows mixers to use a fresh animation context. Ex: If a mixer creates a prop, using a fresh animation context will cause that prop to be destroyed when the mixer finishes, whereas re-using an existing animation context will cause the prop to stick around until the mixer's SI is done.

TunableVariant.name: balloons
TunableVariant.description: Balloons lets you add thought and talk balloons to animations. This is a great way to put extra flavor into animations and helps us stretch our content by creating combinations. Balloon Animation Target is the participant who should display the balloon. Balloon Choices is a reference to the balloon to display, which is its own tunable type. Balloon Delay (and Random Offset) is how long, in real seconds, to delay this balloon after the animation starts. Note: for looping animations, the balloon will always play immediately due to a code limitation. Balloon Target is for showing a balloon of a Sim or Object. Set this to the participant type to show. This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

TunableList.name: enabled
TunableList.description: Balloons lets you add thought and talk balloons to animations. This is a great way to put extra flavor into animations and helps us stretch our content by creating combinations. Balloon Animation Target is the participant who should display the balloon. Balloon Delay (and Random Offset) is how long, in real seconds, to delay this balloon after the animation starts. Note: for looping animations, the balloon will always play immediately due to a code limitation. Balloon Target is for showing a balloon of a Sim or Object. Set this to the participant type to show. This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

TunableList.name: manifests
TunableList.description: Manifests is a complex and seldom used override that lets you change entries in the posture manifest from the ASM. You can see how the fields, Actor, Family, Level, Specific, Left, Right, Back, and Surface, match the manifest entries in the ASM.

TunableList.name: params
TunableList.description: This tuning is used for overriding parameters on the ASM to specific values. These will take precedence over those same settings coming from runtime so be careful! You can enter a number of overrides as key/value pairs: Name is the name of the parameter as it appears in the ASM. Value is the value to set on the ASM. Make sure to get the type right. Parameters are either booleans, enums, or strings. Ex: The most common usage of this field is when tuning the custom parameters on specific objects, such as the objectName parameter.

TunableList.name: prop_state_values
TunableList.description: Tunable mapping from a prop actor name to a list of state values to set. If conflicting data is tuned both here and in the 'props' field, the data inside 'props' will override the data tuned here.

TunableList.name: value
TunableList.description: A list of state values that will be set on the specified actor.

Tunable.description: A new state value to apply to prop_actor.

TunableList.name: props
TunableList.description: The props overrides.

TunableVariant.name: alternative_prop_definitions
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows tuning other ways to override the prop. If none of these ways work, the tuned Definition will be used as a fallback.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Other ways to get a definition ID to override the prop.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_by_definition
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, looks for a favorite object not necessarily in the Sim's inventory.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Tuple to hold the favorite tag to search for and the actor ASM name.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description: If the Sim has a favorite object of this type it will be set as the favorite. If it does not, the tuned definition will be set instead.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_in_inventory
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows looking for and using a favorite object in the Sim's inventory.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description: If the Sim has a favorite object of this type currently in their inventory, it will be used as the prop override. If the Sim doesn't have a favorite of this type, or their favorite is not currently in their inventory, a random object found in their inventory with this tag will be used as the prop override. If there aren't any objects with this tag in the Sim's inventory then the prop override will fall back to the tuned Definition.

TdescFragTag.name: random_choice_tests
TdescFragTag.description: Objects with the favorite tag to be randomly chosen from inventory should pass these tests first.

TunableVariant.name: object_by_participant
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, select the object based on a participant type.

TunableEnum.name: enabled
TunableEnum.description: ParticipantType used to get the object.

TunableVariant.name: replacement_object_based_on_participant
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, define a relationship between the participant and a replacement prop. We use this during proposals to swap the ring prop from the picker object (a ring on a stand) to tuned object (a ring without the stand). This tuning will be ignored if object_by_participant already tuned.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Define the participant and give a list of objects and the replacement prop each one of the objects relates to.

TunableEnum.name: participant
TunableEnum.description: ParticipantType used to get the object.

TunableList.name: prop_replacement_map
TunableList.description: A mapping of participant object to the new replacement prop.

Tunable.name: participant_object
Tunable.description: The object that we want to replace

Tunable.name: replacement_object
Tunable.description: The object that replaces and will appear in the animation

Tunable.name: definition
Tunable.description: The object to create to replace the prop

Tunable.name: from_actor
Tunable.description: The actor name inside the asm to copy the state over.

TunableVariant.name: from_participant
TunableVariant.description: The participant to copy the state over

TunableEnum.name: enabled
TunableEnum.description: The participant type that will be used to get the participant that will provide the override value.

TunableVariant.name: set_as_actor
TunableVariant.description: If enabled the prop defined by override will be set as an actor of the ASM. This is used in cases like setting the chopsticks prop on the eat ASM. In this ASM the chopsticks are set as an Object actor so they can animate. Currently we do not support props playing their own animations.

Tunable.name: actor_name
Tunable.description: Actor name that will be used on the ASM for the prop animation.

TunableVariant.name: sharing
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, this prop may be shared across ASMs.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: With this override tuned, different ASMs can share the same prop. A key can be built out of several elements that allow multiple shares to be active at the same time. No new prop is created if a share is active. Instead, an existing prop is returned and all events operate on that prop (be careful if the animation has visibility events that hide the prop). Conversely, no prop is destroyed until all shares are deactivated. This allows the sharing to be interleaved, such two shares don't necessarily have to relinquish their claim on the prop in inverse order. e.g.: * Sims can leash multiple dogs at the same time (using either hand). For the same hand, there are multiple leashes but only one leash holder prop, which needs to be shared. When the last 'Leash' interaction for that hand ends, the leash holder needs to be destroyed.

TunableList.name: key
TunableList.description: A list of elements that form the key for this share. For keys that are identical, props are shared.

TunableTuple.name: actor
TunableTuple.description: This key is an actor. The object is resolved given the actor name for the specified ASM.

Tunable.name: actor_name
Tunable.description: The actor that is to be used as a key.

TunableTuple.name: literal
TunableTuple.description: This key is a literal string. It's independent of anything that might be set on the ASM.

Tunable.name: literal
Tunable.description: The literal string that is to be used as a key.

TunableTuple.name: parameter
TunableTuple.description: They key is a parameter. Its value is resolved given the parameter name for the specified ASM.

TunableVariant.name: actor_name
TunableVariant.description: The actor for which this parameter's value is to be used.

Tunable.name: Specified
Tunable.description: The actor name.

Tunable.name: parameter_name
Tunable.description: The parameter whose value is to be used.

TunableTuple.name: special_cases
TunableTuple.description: Tuning for special case prop overrides.

TunableVariant.name: set_baby_cloth_from_actor
TunableVariant.description: If tuned, will set the baby's outfit based on a baby that is already an actor in the asm.

TunableList.name: states_to_override
TunableList.description: A list of states that will be transferred from the specified actor to the overridden prop.

Tunable.description: The state to apply on the props from the actor listed above.

TunableVariant.name: reactionlet
TunableVariant.description: Reactionlets are short, one-shot animations that are triggered via x-event. X-events are markers in clips that can trigger an in-game effect that is timed perfectly with the clip. Ex: This is how we trigger laughter at the exact moment of the punchline of a Joke It is EXTREMELY important that only content authored and configured by animators to be used as a Reactionlet gets hooked up as Reactionlet content. If this rule is violated, crazy things will happen including the client and server losing time sync.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Reactionlets are short, one-shot animations that are triggered via x-event. If this rule is violated, crazy things will happen including the client and server losing time sync.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_by_definition
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, looks for a favorite object not necessarily in the Sim's inventory.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description: If the Sim has a favorite object of this type it will be set as the favorite. If it does not, the tuned definition will be set instead.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_in_inventory
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows looking for and using a favorite object in the Sim's inventory.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description: If the Sim has a favorite object of this type currently in their inventory, it will be used as the prop override. If the Sim doesn't have a favorite of this type, or their favorite is not currently in their inventory, a random object found in their inventory with this tag will be used as the prop override. If there aren't any objects with this tag in the Sim's inventory then the prop override will fall back to the tuned Definition.

TdescFragTag.name: random_choice_tests
TdescFragTag.description: Objects with the favorite tag to be randomly chosen from inventory should pass these tests first.

TunableVariant.name: object_by_participant

TunableVariant.name: replacement_object_based_on_participant
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, define a relationship between the participant and a replacement prop. We use this during proposals to swap the ring prop from the picker object (a ring on a stand) to tuned object (a ring without the stand). This tuning will be ignored if object_by_participant already tuned.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Define the participant and give a list of objects and the replacement prop each one of the objects relates to.

TunableEnum.name: participant

TunableVariant.name: set_as_actor
TunableVariant.description: If enabled the prop defined by override will be set as an actor of the ASM. This is used in cases like setting the chopsticks prop on the eat ASM. In this ASM the chopsticks are set as an Object actor so they can animate. Currently we do not support props playing their own animations.

Tunable.name: actor_name
Tunable.description: Actor name that will be used on the ASM for the prop animation.

TunableVariant.name: sharing
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, this prop may be shared across ASMs.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: With this override tuned, different ASMs can share the same prop. A key can be built out of several elements that allow multiple shares to be active at the same time. No new prop is created if a share is active. Instead, an existing prop is returned and all events operate on that prop (be careful if the animation has visibility events that hide the prop). Conversely, no prop is destroyed until all shares are deactivated. This allows the sharing to be interleaved, such two shares don't necessarily have to relinquish their claim on the prop in inverse order. e.g.: * Sims can leash multiple dogs at the same time (using either hand). For the same hand, there are multiple leashes but only one leash holder prop, which needs to be shared. When the last 'Leash' interaction for that hand ends, the leash holder needs to be destroyed.

TunableList.name: key
TunableList.description: A list of elements that form the key for this share. For keys that are identical, props are shared.

TunableTuple.name: actor
TunableTuple.description: This key is an actor. The object is resolved given the actor name for the specified ASM.

Tunable.name: actor_name
Tunable.description: The actor that is to be used as a key.

TunableTuple.name: literal
TunableTuple.description: This key is a literal string. It's independent of anything that might be set on the ASM.

TunableTuple.name: parameter

TunableTuple.description: Override data for the specified effect actor.

TunableVariant.name: callback_event_id
TunableVariant.description: Specifies a callback xevt id we want the vfx to trigger when it fulfills a contracted duty. For example, it can call this xevt on point-to-point vfx if the effect reaches the target event.

TunableVariant.name: effect
TunableVariant.description: Override the actual effect that is meant to be played. It can be left None to stop the effect from playing

TunableVariant.name: effect_joint
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the effect joint of the VFX. Use this specify a different joint name to attach the effect to.

TunableVariant.name: mirrored_effect
TunableVariant.description: If enabled and the is_mirrored parameter comes through as True, we will play this effect instead of the tuned override. NOTE: if you tune this, the non-mirrored version must also be tuned in the regular effect override for it to play. For example, the Bubble Bottle needs to play mirrored effects for left handed Sims, but if we don't override the effect and still want to play a mirrored version, we need to specify the original effect so we don't play nothing.

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: The name of the mirrored effect.

TunableVariant.name: target_joint
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the target joint of the VFX. This is used in case of attractors where we want the effect to target a different place per object on the same animation

TunableVariant.name: target_joint_offset
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the target joint offset of the VFX. This is used in case of point to point VFX where we want the effect to reach a destination offset from the target joint.

Tunable.name: animation_context
Tunable.description: Animation Context - If checked, this animation will get a fresh animation context instead of reusing the animation context of its Interaction. Normally, animation contexts are shared across an entire Super Interaction. This allows mixers to use a fresh animation context. Ex: If a mixer creates a prop, using a fresh animation context will cause that prop to be destroyed when the mixer finishes, whereas re-using an existing animation context will cause the prop to stick around until the mixer's SI is done.

TunableVariant.name: balloons
TunableVariant.description: Balloons lets you add thought and talk balloons to animations. This is a great way to put extra flavor into animations and helps us stretch our content by creating combinations. Balloon Animation Target is the participant who should display the balloon. Balloon Choices is a reference to the balloon to display, which is its own tunable type. Balloon Delay (and Random Offset) is how long, in real seconds, to delay this balloon after the animation starts. Note: for looping animations, the balloon will always play immediately due to a code limitation. Balloon Target is for showing a balloon of a Sim or Object. Set this to the participant type to show. This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

TunableList.name: enabled
TunableList.description: Balloons lets you add thought and talk balloons to animations. This is a great way to put extra flavor into animations and helps us stretch our content by creating combinations. Balloon Animation Target is the participant who should display the balloon. Balloon Choices is a reference to the balloon to display, which is its own tunable type. Balloon Delay (and Random Offset) is how long, in real seconds, to delay this balloon after the animation starts. Note: for looping animations, the balloon will always play immediately due to a code limitation. Balloon Target is for showing a balloon of a Sim or Object. Set this to the participant type to show. This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

TunableList.name: manifests
TunableList.description: Manifests is a complex and seldom used override that lets you change entries in the posture manifest from the ASM. You can see how the fields, Actor, Family, Level, Specific, Left, Right, Back, and Surface, match the manifest entries in the ASM.

TunableList.name: params
TunableList.description: This tuning is used for overriding parameters on the ASM to specific values. These will take precedence over those same settings coming from runtime so be careful! You can enter a number of overrides as key/value pairs: Name is the name of the parameter as it appears in the ASM. Value is the value to set on the ASM. Make sure to get the type right. Parameters are either booleans, enums, or strings. Ex: The most common usage of this field is when tuning the custom parameters on specific objects, such as the objectName parameter.

Tunable.name: one_shot
Tunable.description: If set to true, this behavior will stop running after one iteration.

Tunable.name: parent_relation
Tunable.description: If checked, then this routing behavior is affected by the object's parenting relation: * We'll prefer to route to our previous parent, if it still exists * We'll only route to objects that have no children * We won't route to objects that other objects have picked to route to * We'll stop routing if an object becomes the target's child

Tunable.name: randomize_orientation
Tunable.description: If checked, object will be spawned using a random orientation. Otherwise, it will use the orientation of the target object.

TunableVariant.name: raytest
TunableVariant.description: If enabled then we will run a raytest to make sure that the object remains within LOS.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Data related to running a raytest to a position.

Tunable.name: raytest_end_height_offset
Tunable.description: The height offset of end point of the ray. 1.5 is the height of a Sim.

Tunable.name: raytest_radius
Tunable.description: The radius of the ray. 0.1 is acceptable for a line of sight check.

Tunable.name: raytest_start_height_offset
Tunable.description: The height offset of the start height. 1.5 is the height of a Sim.

TunableVariant.name: starting_position
TunableVariant.description: Use either the previously calculated starting point or perform a raytest in regards to a specific participant.

TunableEnum.name: use_participants_location
TunableEnum.description: A partcipant's location that we will perform the raytest to.

TunableList.name: reference_obj_hidden_flags
TunableList.description: Hidden reasons we allow when retrieving the reference object.

Tunable.name: remove_from_parent_slot
Tunable.description: If checked, objects will be removed from the slot they are parented to when placed in a new location.

TunableList.name: search_flag_set
TunableList.description: Set of flags for FGL Search that will be enabled if present in list. If you're unsure how these flags work, consult your GPE partner.

Tunable.name: skip_plex_starting_position_validation
Tunable.description: If checked, placement of the object will not restrict the starting point of the placement search to inside of the active plex when doing an on-lot placement. For example, if your reference starting point is an object in a common area outside of an apartment unit like a trash chute, and you want to spawn trash next to that trash chute, you would want to check this.

Tunable.name: stay_in_connected_connectivity_group
Tunable.description: If unchecked then the object will be allowed to be placed in a connectivity group that is currently disconnected from the starting location. If checked then the placement will fail if there is not a position inside a connected connectivity group from the starting position that can be used for placement.

Tunable.name: stay_outside_placement
Tunable.description: If checked, objects will run their placement search only for positions that are considered outside.

TunableVariant.name: surface_type_override
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, we will override the routing surface type of the location to whatever is tuned here. Otherwise, we use the routing surface of the initial location. Example: The initial location may be in a pool but you want the created object to be placed on the ground.

TunableEnum.name: enabled
TunableEnum.description: The routing surface we want to force the object to be placed on.

TunableVariant.name: terrain_tags
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, a set of allowed terrain tags. At least one tag must match the terrain under each vertex of the footprint of the supplied object.

TunableTuple.name: slot
TunableTuple.description: The object is slotted somewhere.

TunableVariant.name: parent
TunableVariant.description: The object this object is going to be slotted into.

TunableTuple.name: from_participant
TunableTuple.description: The object is determined by a participant on the resolver.

TunableEnum.name: participant
TunableEnum.description: The participant that determines the object to be used for the specified placement strategy.

TunableTuple.name: from_tags
TunableTuple.description: The object is determined by a set of specified tags.

Tunable.name: shuffle_tag_test_sets
Tunable.description: If False, go through each tag set, in order, and try placement for each matched object (in the order of the tag set indices in object manager). If True, gather all objects matching any tag in all the tag sets, then pick a random one, if placement fails, pick another random one. This supersedes the shuffle_tags_in_test_set.

TunableTuple.description: For each tag set, in order, gather all objects matching any tag in the set. If placement fails, consider another object within the same tag set, then consider objects for the next tag set. If tests are set, for each tag set, gather all objects that match any tag in the set and pass the tests set for the tag set. If placement fails, consider another object that has also passed the tests, then consider objects for the next tag set that also pass the tests set for that tag set. If should_should is True, gather all objects matching any tag, then pick a random one, if placement fails, pick another random one.

Tunable.name: shuffle_tags_in_test_set
Tunable.description: If False, go through each tag within the tag set, in order, try placement for each matched object (in the order of the tag indices in object manager). If True, gather all objects matching any tag within the tag set, then pick a random one, if placement fails, pick another random one.

TunableEnum.description: For each tag, in order, gather objects that match the tag. If the placement fails, consider another object, then consider objects for the next tag. If should_shuffle is True, gather all objects matching any tag, then pick a random one, if placement fails, pick another random one.

TdescFragTag.name: tests
TdescFragTag.description: Tests for matched objects to pass to be considered to try for placement

TunableVariant.name: parent_slot
TunableVariant.description: The slot on location_target where the object should go. This may be either the exact name of a bone on the location_target or a slot type, in which case the first empty slot of the specified type in which the child object fits will be used.

Tunable.name: by_name
Tunable.description: The exact name of a slot on the location_target in which the target object should go.

Tunable.name: by_reference
Tunable.description: A particular slot type in which the target object should go. The first empty slot of this type found on the location_target will be used.

TunableList.name: reference_obj_hidden_flags
TunableList.description: Hidden reasons we allow when retrieving the reference object.

Tunable.name: use_part_owner
Tunable.description: If enabled and target is a part, placement will use the part owner instead of the part.

Tunable.name: needs_route
Tunable.description: If disabled, this behavior will run all surrounding actions without generating a route. An example use case: a chicken may want to target and run an authored path to a particular part of its coop, but the coop is unroutable. This can be disabled to allow that to trigger as a routing behavior without requiring connectivity. Actions that may still run: * no_target_loot * target_action_rules * termination_loot * pre_route_animation Will *not* run routing actions.

TunableTuple.name: target_action_rules
TunableTuple.description: Rules for running TargetObjectActions on the target object. -These will play if the object doesn't perform a route. -By default these will play if the route fails or the behavior is cancelled (see the 'cancel if route incomplete' checkbox below). -These will not play after a hard stop (restarted/destroyed) -This is a good place to tune anything you'd normally tune under 'routing_actions' or if the behavior isn't actually planning a route. Example usage: Assume you have a routing behavior that gets a chicken to move from inside a chicken coop to the nesting slot still within the chicken coop. There is no actual route involved, just an authored path triggered by an animation. We'd tune 'needs route' to false then add the authored path animation as a 'target action rule' so that it plays despite not running a path.

Values <= 0 indicate placement in ocean is invalid." group="General">
<TunableVariant type="None" name="min_water_depth" class="OptionalTunable" default="disabled" display="Min Water Depth" description="(float) If provided, each vertex of the test polygon along with its centroid will be tested to determine whether the ocean water at the test location is at least this deep. Values <= 0 indicate placement on land is valid." group="General">

TunableTuple.name: water_depth_interval
TunableTuple.description: A water depth constraint which defines only the ocean water depth required.

TunableEnum.name: interval
TunableEnum.description: Test if a Sim should be walking, wading or swimming based on the water height offset at a target location and the Sim's wading interval data.

Tunable.name: needs_route
Tunable.description: If disabled, this behavior will run all surrounding actions without generating a route. An example use case: a chicken may want to target and run an authored path to a particular part of its coop, but the coop is unroutable. This can be disabled to allow that to trigger as a routing behavior without requiring connectivity. Actions that may still run: * no_target_loot * target_action_rules * termination_loot * pre_route_animation Will *not* run routing actions.

TunableTuple.name: target_action_rules
TunableTuple.description: Rules for running TargetObjectActions on the target object. -These will play if the object doesn't perform a route. -By default these will play if the route fails or the behavior is cancelled (see the 'cancel if route incomplete' checkbox below). -These will not play after a hard stop (restarted/destroyed) -This is a good place to tune anything you'd normally tune under 'routing_actions' or if the behavior isn't actually planning a route. Example usage: Assume you have a routing behavior that gets a chicken to move from inside a chicken coop to the nesting slot still within the chicken coop. There is no actual route involved, just an authored path triggered by an animation. We'd tune 'needs route' to false then add the authored path animation as a 'target action rule' so that it plays despite not running a path.

TunableList.name: actions
TunableList.description: A set of conditions and a list of one or more TargetObjectActions to run on the target object. These are applied in sequence.

TunableTuple.description: Sets of tests and actions to run on the target object after routing to it.

Tunable.name: abort_if_applied
Tunable.description: Don't run any further actions from this list of action rules if conditions are met and this action is executed.

TunableList.name: actions
TunableList.description: A list of one or more ObjectRoutingBehaviorActions to run on the target object after routing to it. These are applied in sequence.

TunableTuple.name: apply_loot
TunableTuple.description: Action that applies loot.

TunableList.name: loot_actions
TunableList.description: Loot to apply. Participant type 'Actor' refers to the object that is routing (ie, the 'bot'). Participant type 'Object' refers to the target the bot is acting upon.

Tunable.name: use_part_owner
Tunable.description: If enabled and the target is a part, Participant Type 'Object' refers to the target's part owner instead.

TunableTuple.name: destroy_objects
TunableTuple.description: Destroy objects with specific tags, within a defined radius.

TunableVariant.description: If enabled, the animation to play if there are no objects to destroy.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: An animation that can be associated to routing behavior actions.

TunableVariant.name: event_id
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, loot and actions for this route destination is blocked on this event.

TunableList.description: A list of exit conditions to end a looping animation. When exit conditions are met then the looping animation ends.

Tunable.description: The commodity we are gaining.

Tunable.name: state
Tunable.description: The state required to satisfy the condition

Tunable.name: on_trigger
Tunable.description: Satisfy the condition when this state is triggered.

Tunable.description: Minimum amount of time (in sim minutes) for this condition to be satisfied.

Tunable.description: A random chance of this action getting applied (default 100%).

TunableVariant.name: target_part
TunableVariant.description: If tuned, behavior will look for a free part that matches the tuned definition on the chosen target object. This part will be passed to any animation actions. If the target object has no free part, the No Target Loot is applied.

Tunable.name: part_definition

TunableVariant.name: target_participant

TunableEnum.name: target_reservation_timing
TunableEnum.description: Determines if and when we should reserve the target. If setting to NEVER, be sure that your object does not require the behavior to be exclusive against other behaviors or Sim interactions. Reservations will be respected while routing. NEVER - No target reservation required TARGET_ACTION - Reserve only for the target action ROUTING_BEHAVIOR - Reserve for the duration of the entire routing behavior

TunableTuple.name: spawn_points
TunableTuple.description: The waypoints are generated based on spawn points in the world. Sims are forced to be in the open streets before routing through all the waypoints.

Tunable.name: _loops
Tunable.description: The number of loops we want to perform per route.

Tunable.name: constraint_radius
Tunable.description: The radius, in meters, for each of the generated waypoint constraints.

TunableVariant.name: mobile_posture_override
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, the mobile posture specified would require the sim to be in this posture to begin the route. This allows us to make the Sim Swim or Ice Skate instead of walk/run.

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: The mobile posture we want to use.

TunableVariant.name: spawn_point_tags
TunableVariant.description: Controls which spawn points can be used as waypoints.

Tunable.name: use_provided_routing_surface
Tunable.description: If enabled, we will use the target's provided routing surface if it has one.

TunableTuple.name: unobstructed_line
TunableTuple.description: A waypoint generator that builds a series of waypoints in a line and also makes the area around those waypoints unroutable for the duration of the interaction with an update to the navmesh. The line will always begin on the routing sim.

Tunable.name: _loops
Tunable.description: The number of loops we want to perform per route.

TunableTuple.name: fgl_parameters
TunableTuple.description: Arguments that will affect the FGL.

TunableVariant.name: max_water_depth
TunableVariant.description: (float) If provided, each vertex of the line polygon along with its centroid will be tested to determine whether the ocean water at the test location is at most this deep. To disallow water placement, set to 0.

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: Value of the max water depth allowed.

TunableVariant.name: min_water_depth
TunableVariant.description: (float) If provided, each vertex of the line polygon along with its centroid will be tested to determine whether the ocean water at the test location is at least this deep. 0 indicates that all water placement is valid. To allow land placement, leave untuned.

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: Value of the min water depth allowed.

Tunable.name: line_length
Tunable.description: The radius, in meters, of the generated constraint around the target object where the waypoints will be generated.

TunableVariant.name: mobile_posture_override
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, the mobile posture specified would require the sim to be in this posture to begin the route. This allows us to make the Sim Swim or Ice Skate instead of walk/run.

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: The mobile posture we want to use.

Tunable.name: use_provided_routing_surface
Tunable.description: If enabled, we will use the target's provided routing surface if it has one.

TunableTuple.name: none
TunableTuple.description: Routes are generated without waypoints. Each generated location involves a single route. Use this option when the expectation is that routes are generally long (e.g. walkbys). The Sim will route to a waypoint, stop, and then plan for the next waypoint. This looks worse than default stitching, but is more performant.

TunableTuple.name: waypoints
TunableTuple.description: Routes are stitched together using waypoints as long as they are not too long or complex. Use this option when the expectation is that this interaction is confined to a small space and involves short routes. The Sim will route seamlessly through the various waypoints.

Tunable.name: max_distance
Tunable.description: If the route's cumulative distance is more than this value, the route is split.

Tunable.name: max_goals
Tunable.description: If the route has more than this number of goals, the route is split.

TunableList.name: routing_actions
TunableList.description: A list of things the routing object can do once they have reached a routing destination. -These will not play if the object doesn't perform a route, if the route fails, the behavior is cancelled, or after a hard stop (restarted/destroyed). -This is a good place to tune behaviors that you want to happen ONLY if the object reaches its destination. Notes: -Use target_action_rules instead if your route type is FromTargetObject. -If this behavior uses waypoints, routing actions will occur after every waypoint destination is reached. Example usage: Assume you have a routing behavior that gets a robot vacuum to route to a dust pile, play an animation, then destroy the dust pile. The animation and object destruction would be handled as routing actions since they should only occur if the robot vacuum actually reaches the dust pile.

TunableTuple.name: apply_loot
TunableTuple.description: Action that applies loot.

TunableList.name: loot_actions
TunableList.description: Loot to apply. Participant type 'Actor' refers to the object that is routing (ie, the 'bot'). Participant type 'Object' refers to the target the bot is acting upon.

Tunable.name: use_part_owner
Tunable.description: If enabled and the target is a part, Participant Type 'Object' refers to the target's part owner instead.

TunableTuple.name: destroy_objects
TunableTuple.description: Destroy objects with specific tags, within a defined radius.

TunableVariant.name: animation_failure
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, the animation to play if there are no objects to destroy.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: An animation that can be associated to routing behavior actions.

TunableVariant.name: event_id
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, loot and actions for this route destination is blocked on this event.

TunableList.name: loop_exit_conditions
TunableList.description: A list of exit conditions to end a looping animation. When exit conditions are met then the looping animation ends.

TunableList.name: conditions
TunableList.description: A list of conditions that all must be satisfied for the group to be considered satisfied.

TunableVariant.description: A condition that must be satisfied.

Tunable.name: statistic
Tunable.description: The statistic that the event must carry as custom key.

Tunable.name: stat

TunableTuple.name: threshold

Tunable.name: value

TunableEnum.name: who

Tunable.description: The animation to play.

Tunable.name: duration
Tunable.description: How long the rotation animation should play.

Tunable.name: procedural_animation_control_name
Tunable.description: Name of the procedural animation control we want to manipulate.

Tunable.name: rotation_around_facing
Tunable.description: By default we use Y-Axis as up reference when we do rotation. If we set a non-zero angle here, it will also rotate clock-wise about the facing direction. e.g. If we set this as 90 for BB droid's body rotation animation, sphere body will rotate 90 degrees about its facing direction.

Tunable.name: target_joint
Tunable.description: The target joint we want the procedural animation to face to.

TunableList.name: success_loot
TunableList.description: Loot that is applied to the routing object when the behavior completes successfully. -Success in this case means the behavior was not cancelled mid route, a route fail did not occur, and the routing actions have completed successfully. -This loot is not granted after a hard stop (restarted/destroyed). -This is a good place to tune loot that you want to occur at the end of a successful routing behavior run. Example usage: Assume you have a routing behavior that gets a chicken to route to a food pile, eat from it, then 'walk away' if the behavior completed successfully. The state to trigger the 'walk away' behavior would be tuned here. If a sim runs 'call over' on the chicken while it is routing to the food pile, the 'walk away' would be skipped since the behavior did not complete successfully due to it being cancelled by the new behavior pushed by the 'call over' interaction.

TunableList.name: termination_loot
TunableList.description: WARNING: Pushing states here that can trigger new routing behaviors can cause problems. You should tune these state changes in 'routing actions', 'target action rules', or 'success loot'. Loot that is applied to the routing object when the behavior is terminated. -These are granted after normal completion, if any route fails occur, or the behavior is cancelled. -These will not be granted after a hard stop (restarted/destroyed). -This is a good place to tune loot that must occur at the end of the routing behavior. Notes: -There are few valid examples where you'd actually want to use this. In general, a combination of 'success loot' and 'route fail loot' is usually the better option. Example usage: (This is a purely theoretical example) Assume you have a routing behavior that gets an object to route to a location then destroy itself. Let's also assume you want the object to be destroyed no matter if the route failed or the behavior was cancelled. This is where you'd want to tune the destruction loot.

TunableVariant.name: walkstyle_override
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, we will override the default walkstyle for any routes in this routing behavior.

TunableVariant.name: enabled
TunableVariant.description: Specify a walkstyle override to use (either a single walkstyle or pick one based on tests).

TunableTuple.name: single
TunableTuple.description: Wrapper for non-callables used in TunableTestVariant, which will eat additional args and kwargs (resolver, etc) that aren't needed when we are using items such as reference types and other non-callable items.

TunableTuple.name: item
TunableTuple.description: The walkstyle override to use.

TunableList.name: additional_run_flags
TunableList.description: Define where the Sim is allowed to run with the walkstyle. It is combined with Run Allowed Flags from the Routing Component and any Additional Run Flags from walkstyle overrides. These flags may be removed by Removed Run Flags from walkstyle overrides. NOTE: This is *additive*, meaning the resulting run flags for a Sim are defined by the default tuning plus all overrides. However, Removed Run Flags is applied last.

Tunable.name: can_replace_with_short_walkstyle
Tunable.description: If checked, this walkstyle can be replaced with the short walkstyle tuned on the routing component if the path distance is shorter than the short walkstyle distance (also tuned on the routing component). Note that if you never want a certain walkstyle to be replaced by the default short walkstyle, you can use the 'short walkstyle map' (also on the routing component) to override it. Also note that if this walkstyle ends up being replaced via 'Combo Walktyle Replacements' (also on the routing component), the replaced walkstyle will not adhere to this tuning.

TunableEnum.name: priority
TunableEnum.description: The priority of the walkstyle. Higher priority walkstyles will take precedence over lower priority. Equal priority will favor recent requests.

TunableList.name: removed_run_flags
TunableList.description: Modify a Sim's ability to run. It may disable any Run Allowed Flags from the Routing Component or Additional Run Flags added by walkstyle overrides. NOTE: This is *additive* with respect to all overrides, and is applied to the combination of the default tuning plus Additional Run Flags from all overrides. e.g.: The default behavior for a human is to exclusively run outdoors. A hypothetical 'excitable' trait might add the ability to run indoors (meaning the total result is indoors+outdoors). However, the 'pregnant' trait might remove the ability to run (both outdoors and indoors), effectively preventing the Sim from running at all.

Tunable.name: walkstyle
Tunable.description: The locomotion resource (i.e. walkstyle) to request. Depending on the tuned priority and other requests active on the Sim, this may or may not apply immediately.

TunableTuple.name: item
TunableTuple.description: The walkstyle override to use.

TunableList.name: additional_run_flags
TunableList.description: Define where the Sim is allowed to run with the walkstyle. It is combined with Run Allowed Flags from the Routing Component and any Additional Run Flags from walkstyle overrides. These flags may be removed by Removed Run Flags from walkstyle overrides. NOTE: This is *additive*, meaning the resulting run flags for a Sim are defined by the default tuning plus all overrides. However, Removed Run Flags is applied last.

Tunable.name: can_replace_with_short_walkstyle
Tunable.description: If checked, this walkstyle can be replaced with the short walkstyle tuned on the routing component if the path distance is shorter than the short walkstyle distance (also tuned on the routing component). Note that if you never want a certain walkstyle to be replaced by the default short walkstyle, you can use the 'short walkstyle map' (also on the routing component) to override it. Also note that if this walkstyle ends up being replaced via 'Combo Walktyle Replacements' (also on the routing component), the replaced walkstyle will not adhere to this tuning.

TunableEnum.name: priority
TunableEnum.description: The priority of the walkstyle. Higher priority walkstyles will take precedence over lower priority. Equal priority will favor recent requests.

TunableList.name: removed_run_flags
TunableList.description: Modify a Sim's ability to run. It may disable any Run Allowed Flags from the Routing Component or Additional Run Flags added by walkstyle overrides. NOTE: This is *additive* with respect to all overrides, and is applied to the combination of the default tuning plus Additional Run Flags from all overrides. e.g.: The default behavior for a human is to exclusively run outdoors. A hypothetical 'excitable' trait might add the ability to run indoors (meaning the total result is indoors+outdoors). However, the 'pregnant' trait might remove the ability to run (both outdoors and indoors), effectively preventing the Sim from running at all.

Tunable.name: walkstyle
Tunable.description: The locomotion resource (i.e. walkstyle) to request. Depending on the tuned priority and other requests active on the Sim, this may or may not apply immediately.

TdescFragTag.name: tests
TdescFragTag.description: A list of tests groups. At least one must pass all its sub- tests to pass the TestSet. ORs of ANDs
